On May 27, 2006, at 2:45 AM, junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:

>     From: "davek725" david.kissinger@...
>     Date: Fri May 26, 2006 9:54am(PDT)
> Subject: JUnit vs. Agitator
>
> My company is currently doing TDD and using JUnit for our unit
> testing - both persistence testing and business logic testing.  We
> are now looking at Agitator and trying to determine if, and how, it
> fits into our current practices.  I was wondering how others have
> decided to use Agitator (or not use it).  Some of the issues we are
> struggling with:

I've struggled with this myself.  Agitar has some very cool  
capabilities, but I can't figure out when I'd actually use them.  Oh,  
I think the code coverage reports are useful; though I think clover  
overs more value for money in that regard.  The real problem I have  
with Agitar is with the core functionality itself.  I don't really  
know when I'd use the agitation.

The problems I have experienced, when I have tried to use it, stem  
from the fact that random generation of input data is not a  
particularly good way to exercise a function.  Most functions make a  
sequence of decisions about their input data.  If the random  
agitation does not offer data in the appropriate syntax, then the  
agitation simply won't test more than the outer skin of the function.

To put this another way, imagine that you are testing the following  
function:

public boolean isSpecial(String userName);

This function returns true of the userName matches one of a list of  
"special" users.  How is Agitar going to observe this functionality  
unless you build a special factory to create the input values?

Another kind of function that doesn't seem to work well for agitation  
is one that can be called several times and expects a sequence of  
data.  Imagine, for example, the function named:

   public boolean compile(character c);

This function is called, one character at a time, and only returns  
true once a valid line of Java has been entered.  How do you agitate  
this?

Functions like this may seem contrived; but my problem is that when I  
have tried to use Agitar (or it's competitor, JTest) I have  
consistently run in to variations on these themes.  That is,  
functions for which the random generation of input data is  
insufficient to get very far below the surface.

>
> 1.  Agitator looks like it can eliminate the need to write most JUnit
> tests (except true persistence testing).

NO, NO, NO, NO, NO!!!!  First the spirit is wrong.  Second the facts  
are wrong.
TDD is not about HAVING tests, it is about WRITING tests.  If you try  
to generate tests from code, then you might as well not have the  
tests at all; because all you are doing is creating tests that pass.

The most major benefit of TDD is that the author writes everything  
twice, once as a test and once as production code.
(see: http://butunclebob.com/ArticleS.UncleBob.TheSensitivityProblem)

Yet even if you did not accept this argument, remember that Agitation  
can't see very far below the surface.  So the tests that it creates  
would be imperfect at best.

In the end you get an imperfect representation of what IS, rather  
than a separate specification of what you intend.

> The downside is that we
> would be left with only Agitator config files that contain our
> business logic assertions.  This seems like a big leap to take, given
> that if Agitar goes away, we have no JUnit.

JTest provides similar functionality to Agitar, but writes it's  
observations out as JUnit tests.

>
> 2.  Agitator mocks and factories look easy to create, but look like
> they are only useful in the context of Agitator.  I couldn't use them
> for other purposes (e.g. Fitnesse, JUnit).

And again, why would you?  The effort spent on those would be better  
spent on writing unit tests using true TDD.

>
> 3.  Having my business logic tests in JUnit means they are in an
> understood format and things such as inputs and expected results are
> clearly visible and grouped with each test.  My impression of
> Agitator is that this wouldn't be as clear.

Certainly true. This was one of my early complaints about the product  
before I dug beneath the surface.

The bottom line is that this is a very interesting product that  
appears to me to be looking for a problem to solve. I'm not at all  
sure how I would use it to solve any of the problems that my teams  
currently have.  I think the random generation of input data is  
interesting, and can be beneficial for simple syntax and validation  
issues; but Agitar is NOT a replacement for TDD; and NOBODY should  
think that the tool can write your unit tests for you.  Remember.  
TEST FIRST!, not Agitate second.
